thread.title: Cards seek to end FSU's long ACC win streak
thread.title_full: Cards seek to end FSU's long ACC win streak

title: Cards seek to end FSU's long ACC win streak
text:
Cards seek to end FSU's long ACC win streak Steve Jones , @stevejones_cj 5:28 p.m. EDT October 16, 2015 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | Steve Jones on UofL's upcoming game against Florida State | 06:37 The C-J's Steve Jones and Jeff Greer discuss UofL's game against Florida State and what the Cardinals need to do to get a win against the Seminoles. Video by Jeff Faughender 1 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | Bobby Petrino previews Florida State | 15:51 After an open date, the Louisville football team gets a tall task this week in facing Florida State and superstar running back Dalvin Cook. Pat McDonogh, The C-J 2 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | Grantham previews FSU | 04:19 U of L defensive coordinator Todd Grantham discusses FSU's Everett Golson and Dalvin Cook. 3 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | Burgess previews FSU game | 02:50 UofL linebacker James Burgess, who is from the Miami area, is looking forward to the FSU game in his home state. 4 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | Appleby on his punting success | 04:59 U of L senior punter Josh Appleby is off to strong start. 5 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | FSU's Jimbo Fisher on Louisville, Spurrier and injuries | 08:01 Florida State football coach Jimbo Fisher speaks after practice on Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2015. 6 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | Jamari Staples says it's good to be back | 06:06 The U of L wide receiver is happy to be back after his injury. Pat McDonogh, The C-J 7 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK James Quick previews FSU game | 03:22 WR says Cards' speed can match up 8 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | FSU linebacker on facing Lamar Jackson | 03:01 Florida State defensive lineman Jacob Pugh speaks with media after practice on Oct. 13, 2015. 9 of 10 VIDEOS | U OF L FOOTBALL-FSU WEEK Video | McGee previews FSU game | 06:50 Louisville offensive coordinator Garrick McGee says Cards' freshmen developing well. 10 of 10 Video | Steve Jones on UofL's upcoming game against Florida State Video | Bobby Petrino previews Florida State Video | Grantham previews FSU Video | Burgess previews FSU game Video | Appleby on his punting success Video | FSU's Jimbo Fisher on Louisville, Spurrier and injuries Video | Jamari Staples says it's good to be back James Quick previews FSU game Video | FSU linebacker on facing Lamar Jackson Video | McGee previews FSU game Oct 10, 2015; Tallahassee, FL, USA; A flag bearer waves the Florida State Seminoles flag after a score in the second quarter of their game against the Miami Hurricanes at Doak Campbell Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Phil Sears-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Phil Sears, Phil Sears-USA TODAY Sports) 11 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. – Without a slip-up for three years running, Florida State has been running the Atlantic Coast Conference. 
The University of Louisville will try to upset the balance of power at noon Saturday. 
When the Cardinals (2-3, 1-1 ACC) visit Doak Campbell Stadium, the No. 11 Seminoles (5-0, 3-0) will have a 27-game ACC winning streak on the line as well as a 17-game home winning streak. 
For Louisville, it’s another ACC debut trip to one of the conference’s signature football destinations, and the Cards have a chance to make a major statement while playing in a state they recruit heavily. 
If Louisville were to win, it’s hard to imagine FSU’s first ACC loss since October 2012 wouldn't receive national notoriety. Louisville vs. Florida State football team | 3 keys and a prediction 
“They have been the premier team in our league with the national championship (two years ago) and a trip to the playoffs last year,” Louisville coach Bobby Petrino said. “So it's a great challenge for us, and you certainly get excited. Our guys have a lot of energy and a lot of focus.” 
After losing 11 NFL draft selections, including No. 1 pick and former Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback Jameis Winston, the Seminoles, who are favored by a touchdown Saturday, aren’t seen as quite the juggernaut of years past. FSU, which was picked second behind Clemson in the ACC Atlantic Division in the preseason media poll, is averaging just 22.3 points in its three ACC games after averaging 33.7 against power-conference teams last year and 47.9 against BCS-conference opponents in 2013. 
Now with Notre Dame graduate transfer Everett Golson playing quarterback instead of Winston, FSU is averaging 229 yards passing, about 74 fewer than in 2014. A homecoming for U of L players and coaches 
But the Noles have a new superstar in electric running back Dalvin Cook. 
The sophomore is coming off a 222-yard rushing game against Miami, and his average of 158 yards per game is second-best in the Football Bowl Subdivision. He’s helped FSU average 203 yards per game on the ground in all, about 65 more than in 2014. 
“They don't get a lot better (than Cook),” FSU coach Jimbo Fisher said. “He's a very special guy. And ability, we get caught up in that, it's phenomenal. But it's the intangibles, man. I mean, it's just the ability to compete, the ability to learn, the mental toughness, the fortitude, and his drive to be great.” 
FSU’s defense is improved, too. The Seminoles are allowing just 14 points per game and have the nation’s No. 22 total defense after ranking No. 63 in 2014. 
Louisville offensive coordinator Garrick McGee said the Seminoles feature a fast defense that usually has at least five defensive backs on the field at all times. 
“Most of the games we’ve studied, they have forced the offense to not play very well,” McGee said. 5 questions | Breaking down Florida State 
Louisville will try to get another big game from freshman quarterback Lamar Jackson, a Floridian who was recruited by the Seminoles. He’ll be seeking his third consecutive – and fourth overall – 100-yard rushing game while the Cards also try to jump-start their passing and get more of their backs rolling in the run game. 
That endeavor includes another week in Louisville’s seemingly never-ending search to find its best mix of five offensive linemen. U of L has started nine different O-linemen so far this season. 
True freshman offensive tackle Kenny Thomas made his debut as a starter against NC State on Oct. 3, and it’s possible U of L will tweak the lineup again if it brings back former starter Tobijah Hughley as the No. 1 center or tries junior-college transfer Kiola Mahoni – “a very, very powerful run-blocker,” Petrino said – as a No. 1 guard for the first time. 
The coach said his team worked hard on shoring up the overall running game during its off week, and Petrino’s teams tend to do well following a break. He is 15-5 as a head coach in regular season games in which he had at least eight days to prepare. U of L alternate uniforms back for FSU game 
U of L put a scare into FSU in 2014, leading 21-0 in the second quarter before succumbing to a Winston-led rally and losing 42-31. 
Even though Louisville started 0-3 this season, a victory Saturday would position the Cards still to reach just about any preseason expectations. The second half of their schedule looks more manageable on paper, and a U of L team that could defeat FSU on the road could very well be favored to win each of its remaining games. 
“It would mean everything (to beat FSU),” receiver James Quick said. 
U of L linebacker James Burgess said winning Saturday would provide some payback after the Noles won in the Cards’ stadium last year, and it would boost U of L’s chances in the ACC. 
“We know we’re on the road right now,” he said. “Our defense is playing with confidence. Our offense is playing with confidence. We’re studying a lot of film. We’re very confident and doing a good week of preparing. I think we’re ready." 11 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://cjky.it/1LyvdDc TOP VIDEOS
